I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there is no valid reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are so many factors to consider that it cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin - heads can never be tails, but they are essentially the same. There are various civil rights associated with this, such as property taxes and healthcare, where a partner cannot be present if you are sick, as they are not technically considered family. I think this is absurd if you are spending the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar rates of success and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. What many people seem to get hung up on is that homosexuals are not asking for the right to get married in a church, but rather a legal marriage certificate provided by the government. If there is no involvement with church and state, this shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why people like Catholics would object to this on religious grounds, as it is a legal matter. If you are allowing someone a civil union, why not also allow them a legal marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. I think the federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should reflect this. However, I think President Bush has strong views on this matter, and his stance on gay marriage aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard against it are moral, but morality differs from person to person. To embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest is unethical. It's hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage while considering recent controversies such as the pledge of allegiance. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but this is not a valid reason. The American Psychological Association has stated that this is untrue. Institutions that actually do research should be listened to instead of popular opinion or religious beliefs.

First off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. You know, just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it has beneficial properties. So, I’d say no to making it available to the public. Absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I’d say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it’s beneficial; it’s not beneficial. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are a bunch of drugs that are illegal but pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Perocets, that kind of thing. And those are controlled substances. But we use them all the time because they’re beneficial. And if you deny that, just because there’s a taboo around marijuana, then there’s no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don’t think it’s that similar to alcohol because if you abuse marijuana, although if you abuse alcohol too, that can lead to bad things. It’s a tough one. I’d say you could integrate it, like let it become legal gradually but not all at once. Because then it would be abused, but if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it’s an illegal drug. But I mean, it’s not that bad for you. It’s not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. So, I mean, if we get rid of that image of marijuana as being this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly. And certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the twenty-first century. It's not as strict as it used to be. I remember growing up, I would always go to church every Sunday and wear cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there on the weekends. Now, as I've gotten older, they've started a teenager's mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during the summer. Families often come in late, so I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to get dressed up, people now wear jeans and khakis. I think the biggest change I've noticed is that the church I know doesn't involve me in its politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by changing policies like allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry. There are married men who become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. It's the individual, not the policies. I think that if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should consider a different faith. The sexuality of these priests might be based on genetics, not how they were brought up. I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening if they didn't know about it and were trying to cover it up. Shame on them if they did know and didn't act. As for other thoughts, I don't have any.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still very much shaken by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq based on flimsy pretexts. Early on, the Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which turned out to be false.

That really rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war still upsets me. It seems to me that the Bush administration was very open about deceiving the American people and has yet to take responsibility. Even Colin Powell, who later admitted that he wasn’t convinced by the evidence when he presented it to the UN, called it a mistake.

That’s an impeachable offense, in my opinion. The Bush administration has shown complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to undermine it since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t remember the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made that allegation in his book after he was likely forced out of office, but it seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly due to his father’s administration. I think he also aimed to secure our energy supply, which is a very underhanded approach.

I think we should have pulled out a long time ago. Pulling out now could lead to a civil war, which would result in more deaths. The alternative proposed by the UN and the US, a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the best idea because it could also lead to long-term issues regarding Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, and the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister lacks control, and radical elements are vying for power.

I really don’t feel that it’s appropriate to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. I think it’s up to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. I feel that attempting to impose any kind of power over this issue would be against what has already been written in the constitution. I believe those trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in areas like Boston. I don’t think it’s the government’s place to decide what churches can and can’t make illegal. The separation of church and state is a key aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the United States. Even if an amendment were to be made, I think it would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don’t think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don’t see why he’s pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. I really feel it’s up to the churches, not the president or anyone in government, to decide this. There isn’t a good reason for an amendment banning it, as I don’t see how it would impact the economy or society positively.

Ok, the war in Iraq.

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which, in reality, had little to do with each other. The government exploited the public's outrage against the attacks to push for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I myself am strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes. The war in Iraq, in many ways, is reminiscent of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes, such as the high number of American soldiers who died. They removed Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath, including the power vacuum and chaos that ensued. The United States was attempting to install a democratic government, similar to their efforts in Vietnam. However, the government underestimated the difficulty and duration of the process.

I believe the government was not adequately prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We are still there, at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. The long process of training Iraqi troops and police forces is ongoing. The government may have tried to deceive the American people into believing it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. Implementing a new form of government takes years and is not an easy process, as seen in our own history.

The decision to go to war is difficult. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken away their government and way of life. However, we also need to consider the high risk and cost to American lives. Moreover, if the goal is to create a democratic nation, why just Iraq? The main reason is likely oil, as it's a significant source of our energy. The government's claims of Iraq having weapons of mass destruction turned out to be false, unlike in the case of North Korea, where we know they exist but have not attacked.

I hope that this war ends soon and that there will be peace, but I doubt that will happen.

I feel like the war has been prolonged for too long. Initially, the purpose was good, which was to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have lost sight of that purpose and are now fighting for the sake of proving our power. I think the original motivation had questionable aspects, such as George Bush's father's previous disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be justifiable, but if personal matters were involved, it would not be fair. I believe the war has been prolonged too much. Initially, starting the war was a clear statement, but it has dragged on for over a year now. If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I don't think our reason has remained consistent over time; it seems we are still at war just to be at war, and we don't want to leave without a decisive victory. I think the war has gone on long enough and should stop. There comes a point when the country's officials must fend for themselves. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions of dollars on this war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty. This war is a long-term drain on our economy. We should be spending that money on improving our own country, such as fixing roads and schools, and addressing healthcare issues. Right now, that money is being spent to kill our own citizens in a war we've lost the cause for. I think that's it.

My understanding is that they did not legalize it; they decriminalized it. This means it was reduced from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—something you might get cited for instead of being booked and arrested. When someone gets caught and cited for it, there are still potential ramifications, such as issues with job interviews and other formal situations, which are usually the worst effects of a drug charge. At least with a marijuana charge, people often worry about these long-term effects, even if it's decriminalized.

However, there's an argument that arresting and processing people can be expensive. It involves costs for booking, housing, court proceedings, and legal representation. Municipalities facing financial difficulties might not be willing to take on these additional expenses, even if it could free up funding for other public needs. In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it might be accepted. Here, the city might have more money to spend on education, social programs, and food assistance for the homeless due to the financial benefits.

I don't think everyone wants marijuana to be widely available and smoked everywhere, as it could be awkward and not socially accepted in many places. Additionally, it's hard to generalize about the effects of substances like marijuana and alcohol. They both have adverse effects on people, and individuals react differently based on their personal characteristics. Some people might use substances moderately, while others might not. Ultimately, both substances can have negative impacts, but how they affect each other can vary greatly from person to person.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there is no valid reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are so many factors to consider that it cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin - heads can never be tails, but they are essentially the same. There are various civil rights associated with this, such as property taxes and healthcare, where a partner cannot be present if you are sick, as they are not technically considered family. I think this is absurd if you are spending the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar rates of success and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. What many people seem to get hung up on is that homosexuals are not asking for the right to get married in a church, but rather a legal marriage certificate provided by the government. If there is no involvement with church and state, this shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why people like Catholics would object to this on religious grounds, as it is a legal matter. If you are allowing someone a civil union, why not also allow them a legal marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. I think the federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should reflect this. However, I think President Bush has strong views on this matter, and his stance on gay marriage aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard against it are moral, but morality differs from person to person. To embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest is unethical. It's hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage while considering recent controversies such as the pledge of allegiance. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but this is not a valid reason. The American Psychological Association has stated that this is untrue. Institutions that actually do research should be listened to instead of popular opinion or religious beliefs.

First off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. You know, just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it has beneficial properties. So, I’d say no to making it available to the public. Absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I’d say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it’s beneficial; it’s not beneficial. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are a bunch of drugs that are illegal but pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Perocets, that kind of thing. And those are controlled substances. But we use them all the time because they’re beneficial. And if you deny that, just because there’s a taboo around marijuana, then there’s no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don’t think it’s that similar to alcohol because if you abuse marijuana, although if you abuse alcohol too, that can lead to bad things. It’s a tough one. I’d say you could integrate it, like let it become legal gradually but not all at once. Because then it would be abused, but if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it’s an illegal drug. But I mean, it’s not that bad for you. It’s not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. So, I mean, if we get rid of that image of marijuana as being this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly. And certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the twenty-first century. It's not as strict as it used to be. I remember growing up, I would always go to church every Sunday and wear cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there on the weekends. Now, as I've gotten older, they've started a teenager's mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during the summer. Families often come in late, so I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to get dressed up, people now wear jeans and khakis. I think the biggest change I've noticed is that the church I know doesn't involve me in its politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by changing policies like allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry. There are married men who become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. It's the individual, not the policies. I think that if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should consider a different faith. The sexuality of these priests might be based on genetics, not how they were brought up. I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening if they didn't know about it and were trying to cover it up. Shame on them if they did know and didn't act. As for other thoughts, I don't have any.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still very much shaken by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq based on flimsy pretexts. Early on, the Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which turned out to be false.

That really rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war still upsets me. It seems to me that the Bush administration was very open about deceiving the American people and has yet to take responsibility. Even Colin Powell, who later admitted that he wasn’t convinced by the evidence when he presented it to the UN, called it a mistake.

That’s an impeachable offense, in my opinion. The Bush administration has shown complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to undermine it since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t remember the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made that allegation in his book after he was likely forced out of office, but it seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly due to his father’s administration. I think he also aimed to secure our energy supply, which is a very underhanded approach.

I think we should have pulled out a long time ago. Pulling out now could lead to a civil war, which would result in more deaths. The alternative proposed by the UN and the US, a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the best idea because it could also lead to long-term issues regarding Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, and the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister lacks control, and radical elements are vying for power.

I really don’t feel that it’s appropriate to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. I think it’s up to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. I feel that attempting to impose any kind of power over this issue would be against what has already been written in the constitution. I believe those trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in areas like Boston. I don’t think it’s the government’s place to decide what churches can and can’t make illegal. The separation of church and state is a key aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the United States. Even if an amendment were to be made, I think it would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don’t think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don’t see why he’s pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. I really feel it’s up to the churches, not the president or anyone in government, to decide this. There isn’t a good reason for an amendment banning it, as I don’t see how it would impact the economy or society positively.

Ok, the war in Iraq.

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which, in reality, had little to do with each other. The government exploited the public's outrage against the attacks to push for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I myself am strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes. The war in Iraq, in many ways, is reminiscent of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes, such as the high number of American soldiers who died. They removed Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath, including the power vacuum and chaos that ensued. The United States was attempting to install a democratic government, similar to their efforts in Vietnam. However, the government underestimated the difficulty and duration of the process.

I believe the government was not adequately prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We are still there, at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. The long process of training Iraqi troops and police forces is ongoing. The government may have tried to deceive the American people into believing it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. Implementing a new form of government takes years and is not an easy process, as seen in our own history.

The decision to go to war is difficult. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken away their government and way of life. However, we also need to consider the high risk and cost to American lives. Moreover, if the goal is to create a democratic nation, why just Iraq? The main reason is likely oil, as it's a significant source of our energy. The government's claims of Iraq having weapons of mass destruction turned out to be false, unlike in the case of North Korea, where we know they exist but have not attacked.

I hope that this war ends soon and that there will be peace, but I doubt that will happen.

I feel like the war has been prolonged for too long. Initially, the purpose was good, which was to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have lost sight of that purpose and are now fighting for the sake of proving our power. I think the original motivation had questionable aspects, such as George Bush's father's previous disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be justifiable, but if personal matters were involved, it would not be fair. I believe the war has been prolonged too much. Initially, starting the war was a clear statement, but it has dragged on for over a year now. If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I don't think our reason has remained consistent over time; it seems we are still at war just to be at war, and we don't want to leave without a decisive victory. I think the war has gone on long enough and should stop. There comes a point when the country's officials must fend for themselves. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions of dollars on this war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty. This war is a long-term drain on our economy. We should be spending that money on improving our own country, such as fixing roads and schools, and addressing healthcare issues. Right now, that money is being spent to kill our own citizens in a war we've lost the cause for. I think that's it.

My understanding is that they did not legalize it; they decriminalized it. This means it was reduced from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—something you might get cited for instead of being booked and arrested. When someone gets caught and cited for it, there are still potential ramifications, such as issues with job interviews and other formal situations, which are usually the worst effects of a drug charge. At least with a marijuana charge, people often worry about these long-term effects, even if it's decriminalized.

However, there's an argument that arresting and processing people can be expensive. It involves costs for booking, housing, court proceedings, and legal representation. Municipalities facing financial difficulties might not be willing to take on these additional expenses, even if it could free up funding for other public needs. In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it might be accepted. Here, the city might have more money to spend on education, social programs, and food assistance for the homeless due to the financial benefits.

I don't think everyone wants marijuana to be widely available and smoked everywhere, as it could be awkward and not socially accepted in many places. Additionally, it's hard to generalize about the effects of substances like marijuana and alcohol. They both have adverse effects on people, and individuals react differently based on their personal characteristics. Some people might use substances moderately, while others might not. Ultimately, both substances can have negative impacts, but how they affect each other can vary greatly from person to person.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there is no valid reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are so many factors to consider that it cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin - heads can never be tails, but they are essentially the same. There are various civil rights associated with this, such as property taxes and healthcare, where a partner cannot be present if you are sick, as they are not technically considered family. I think this is absurd if you are spending the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar rates of success and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. What many people seem to get hung up on is that homosexuals are not asking for the right to get married in a church, but rather a legal marriage certificate provided by the government. If there is no involvement with church and state, this shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why people like Catholics would object to this on religious grounds, as it is a legal matter. If you are allowing someone a civil union, why not also allow them a legal marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. I think the federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should reflect this. However, I think President Bush has strong views on this matter, and his stance on gay marriage aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard against it are moral, but morality differs from person to person. To embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest is unethical. It's hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage while considering recent controversies such as the pledge of allegiance. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but this is not a valid reason. The American Psychological Association has stated that this is untrue. Institutions that actually do research should be listened to instead of popular opinion or religious beliefs.

First off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. You know, just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it has beneficial properties. So, I’d say no to making it available to the public. Absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I’d say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it’s beneficial; it’s not beneficial. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are a bunch of drugs that are illegal but pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Perocets, that kind of thing. And those are controlled substances. But we use them all the time because they’re beneficial. And if you deny that, just because there’s a taboo around marijuana, then there’s no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don’t think it’s that similar to alcohol because if you abuse marijuana, although if you abuse alcohol too, that can lead to bad things. It’s a tough one. I’d say you could integrate it, like let it become legal gradually but not all at once. Because then it would be abused, but if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it’s an illegal drug. But I mean, it’s not that bad for you. It’s not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. So, I mean, if we get rid of that image of marijuana as being this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly. And certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the twenty-first century. It's not as strict as it used to be. I remember growing up, I would always go to church every Sunday and wear cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there on the weekends. Now, as I've gotten older, they've started a teenager's mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during the summer. Families often come in late, so I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to get dressed up, people now wear jeans and khakis. I think the biggest change I've noticed is that the church I know doesn't involve me in its politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by changing policies like allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry. There are married men who become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. It's the individual, not the policies. I think that if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should consider a different faith. The sexuality of these priests might be based on genetics, not how they were brought up. I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening if they didn't know about it and were trying to cover it up. Shame on them if they did know and didn't act. As for other thoughts, I don't have any.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still very much shaken by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq based on flimsy pretexts. Early on, the Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which turned out to be false.

That really rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war still upsets me. It seems to me that the Bush administration was very open about deceiving the American people and has yet to take responsibility. Even Colin Powell, who later admitted that he wasn’t convinced by the evidence when he presented it to the UN, called it a mistake.

That’s an impeachable offense, in my opinion. The Bush administration has shown complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to undermine it since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t remember the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made that allegation in his book after he was likely forced out of office, but it seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly due to his father’s administration. I think he also aimed to secure our energy supply, which is a very underhanded approach.

I think we should have pulled out a long time ago. Pulling out now could lead to a civil war, which would result in more deaths. The alternative proposed by the UN and the US, a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the best idea because it could also lead to long-term issues regarding Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, and the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister lacks control, and radical elements are vying for power.

I really don’t feel that it’s appropriate to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. I think it’s up to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. I feel that attempting to impose any kind of power over this issue would be against what has already been written in the constitution. I believe those trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in areas like Boston. I don’t think it’s the government’s place to decide what churches can and can’t make illegal. The separation of church and state is a key aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the United States. Even if an amendment were to be made, I think it would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don’t think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don’t see why he’s pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. I really feel it’s up to the churches, not the president or anyone in government, to decide this. There isn’t a good reason for an amendment banning it, as I don’t see how it would impact the economy or society positively.

Ok, the war in Iraq.

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which, in reality, had little to do with each other. The government exploited the public's outrage against the attacks to push for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I myself am strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes. The war in Iraq, in many ways, is reminiscent of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes, such as the high number of American soldiers who died. They removed Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath, including the power vacuum and chaos that ensued. The United States was attempting to install a democratic government, similar to their efforts in Vietnam. However, the government underestimated the difficulty and duration of the process.

I believe the government was not adequately prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We are still there, at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. The long process of training Iraqi troops and police forces is ongoing. The government may have tried to deceive the American people into believing it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. Implementing a new form of government takes years and is not an easy process, as seen in our own history.

The decision to go to war is difficult. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken away their government and way of life. However, we also need to consider the high risk and cost to American lives. Moreover, if the goal is to create a democratic nation, why just Iraq? The main reason is likely oil, as it's a significant source of our energy. The government's claims of Iraq having weapons of mass destruction turned out to be false, unlike in the case of North Korea, where we know they exist but have not attacked.

I hope that this war ends soon and that there will be peace, but I doubt that will happen.

I feel like the war has been prolonged for too long. Initially, the purpose was good, which was to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have lost sight of that purpose and are now fighting for the sake of proving our power. I think the original motivation had questionable aspects, such as George Bush's father's previous disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be justifiable, but if personal matters were involved, it would not be fair. I believe the war has been prolonged too much. Initially, starting the war was a clear statement, but it has dragged on for over a year now. If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I don't think our reason has remained consistent over time; it seems we are still at war just to be at war, and we don't want to leave without a decisive victory. I think the war has gone on long enough and should stop. There comes a point when the country's officials must fend for themselves. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions of dollars on this war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty. This war is a long-term drain on our economy. We should be spending that money on improving our own country, such as fixing roads and schools, and addressing healthcare issues. Right now, that money is being spent to kill our own citizens in a war we've lost the cause for. I think that's it.

My understanding is that they did not legalize it; they decriminalized it. This means it was reduced from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—something you might get cited for instead of being booked and arrested. When someone gets caught and cited for it, there are still potential ramifications, such as issues with job interviews and other formal situations, which are usually the worst effects of a drug charge. At least with a marijuana charge, people often worry about these long-term effects, even if it's decriminalized.

However, there's an argument that arresting and processing people can be expensive. It involves costs for booking, housing, court proceedings, and legal representation. Municipalities facing financial difficulties might not be willing to take on these additional expenses, even if it could free up funding for other public needs. In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it might be accepted. Here, the city might have more money to spend on education, social programs, and food assistance for the homeless due to the financial benefits.

I don't think everyone wants marijuana to be widely available and smoked everywhere, as it could be awkward and not socially accepted in many places. Additionally, it's hard to generalize about the effects of substances like marijuana and alcohol. They both have adverse effects on people, and individuals react differently based on their personal characteristics. Some people might use substances moderately, while others might not. Ultimately, both substances can have negative impacts, but how they affect each other can vary greatly from person to person.

I was raised in a Christian family, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe that it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. I feel that it should be decided by each state rather than the president deciding for the whole country.

Many states are democratic, and many are republican. Democratic states will likely push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. I don't think you should disagree with a state's decision if they choose to legalize it, as you chose to live there. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel like it should be legalized based on each state's discretion.
